body.body: Before starting work, ensure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported. This will help prevent it from falling and causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
Before removing the forks, release the top yoke clamp fixing and loosen the top cap a little to allow easier removal during strip-down.
Note the position of the rebound damping adjuster to ensure the setting is retained on re-assembly.
Turn the spring preload adjuster fully anti-clockwise to the softest setting. Make a note of the number of turns to ensure the setting is retained on re-assembly.

Do not change the fork adjustment settings. If they are changed, this will change the handling of the motorcycle from those which the rider is used to. Riding with unfamiliar fork settings may cause unexpected handling characteristics leading to loss of control and an accident.
The fork seals can be renewed without removal of the damping cylinder. Unless removal of the damping cylinder is necessary, omit steps 19 and 20 of this procedure.
clamp the fork outer tube, then unscrew the top cap from the outer tube.
Never tightly clamp the outer tube as this will cause the tube to permanently distort. A distorted tube is not serviceable and must be replaced.
The top cap is not under spring tension and will not spring upwards when the threads disengage.
Holding the inner and outer tubes together, invert the fork and pour out the fork oil into a suitable container.
Allow the outer tube to slide down the inner to allow access to the spring spacer.

While compressing the fork spring and while the spring holder is in place always wear protective equipment for the face and eyes and never stand directly above or look directly down on the fork. If the spring compressor or holder should dislodge or detach, the resulting release of spring tension could cause parts to fly off resulting in injury to the user.
over the top cap. Position the two adjustable arms to the holes in the spring spacer. Screw in the arms until they positively engage in the spring spacer holes.
, manually compress the fork spring and insert the spring holder as shown, below the damper locknut.
Loosen the locknut, unscrew and remove the top cap and the damper rod, taking care not to bend the rod. The top cap assembly cannot be dismantled.
Recompress the fork spring to remove the holder.
Pump the damper rod to remove all the oil.

While compressing the fork spring and while the spring holder is in place always wear protective equipment for the face and eyes and never stand directly above or look directly down on the fork. If the spring compressor or holder should dislodge or detach, the resulting release of spring tension could cause parts to fly off resulting in injury to the user.
Remove the nylon spacer, spring collar and spring. It is not necessary to remove the bump rubber if still attached to the top cap.
Raise the inner tube and remove the dust seal and circlip from the outer tube.

and, using a slide hammer action to release the oil seal and bushes from the outer tube, separate the inner and outer tubes leaving the seals and bushes in place on the inner tube. Note the relative positions and orientation of all bushes and seals before removal.
To allow the removal of the seals and bushes, carefully remove the upper bush from the inner tube.
Remove the damper fixing from the bottom of the fork.
Remove the damping cylinder from the inner tube.

title: Front Fork - Disassembly
